Then King AjÄtaÅ›atru, seeing that the assembly of bodhisattvas and Å›rÄvakas had finished their meal and washed their bowls, took a low seat, sat in front of PÅ«rá¹‡a, and wished to listen to the Dharma:

The doubts of the great king cannot be resolved by buddhas equal to the sands of the Ganges.
At that time, the king reflected on himself, having no savior and no protector, and fell from his seat, like a great tree broken and fallen to the ground.
MahÄkÄÅ›yapa said:
Great king, be at ease. Do not be afraid or terrified.
Why is it so?
The youth PÅ«rá¹‡a is clad in the armor of great virtue. He skillfully employs expedient means and sets forth these words. You may ask slowly.
At that time, the king immediately rose and asked PÅ«rá¹‡a:
What did you say just now:
'The World-Honored Buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges cannot resolve my doubts for me?'
Boshu replied:
What do you think, O King?
Do the World-Honored Buddhas act based on the mind?
He replied:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
Boshu asked again:
Do the World-Honored Buddhas act based on the mind?
He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
He asked again:
Do the World-Honored Buddhas act based on the cessation of the mind?
He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
He asked again:
Do the World-Honored Buddhas act based on conditioned things?
He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
He asked again:
Do the World-Honored Buddhas act based on unconditioned things?
He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
He asked again:
Do the World-Honored Buddhas act based on the unconditioned things they teach?
He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
Boshu also said:
What does the king think?
The various dharmas are without practice, and without practice there is nowhere to return to. Can anyone teach and decisively understand the Dharma?
He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
The king should understand this, and therefore I say these words:
'The king's doubts are not something that Buddhas of the ten directions can resolve.' Furthermore, great king!
Suppose someone were to say:
'I can pollute the empty sky with dust, darkness, ash, smoke, and fog.'
Is that possible?
He replied:
It cannot be polluted.
Boshu asked again:
Suppose, great king!
If I were to take this empty sky and wash it to make it clean, would that be possible?
He replied:
It cannot.
Boshu said:
Great king!
The body of the TathÄgata understands all dharmas to be like empty space, attaining supreme perfect enlightenment naturally and purely, without defilement.
For this reason, what existing dharmas could be defiled, seen as having limits?
How could one decisively understand them as being pure and removed?
Great King, contemplate this meaning. Therefore, I said earlier:
'The buddhas, world-honored ones, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, are unable to decisively understand.'
Furthermore, Great King!
The buddhas, world-honored ones, do not attain the inner mind and abide in it;
They do not attain the outer mind and abide in it.
Why is this?
All dharmas are naturally pure and have no location, naturally pure and have no location, with no aspiration and no abiding.
Why is this?
Is it because one attains mastery? It is because all dharmas are natural.
Is it because there is no nature? It is because all dharmas are without establishment.
There is no stumbling, because all dharmas are non-existent.
There is no existence, because all dharmas are free from form and appearance.
There is no form and appearance, because all dharmas are empty and void.ğŸ”½There is no obstruction, because all dharmas are without characteristics.
There is no teaching, because all dharmas are naturally non-existent.
Free from existence, because all dharmas are liberated.ğŸ”½There is no liberation, because all dharmas are without separation.
There is no separation, because all dharmas are unborn.
There is no reliance, because all dharmas are naturally pure.
The nature of the mind is pure, because all dharmas are equal to space.
There is no comparison, because all dharmas have no companions.ğŸ”½There are no companions, because all dharmas are free from duality.
There is no duality, because all dharmas are tranquil.ğŸ”½There is no measure, because all dharmas are uninterrupted.
There are no boundaries, because all dharmas have no limits.
How can it be true? Because all dharmas are inverted and abide in what is not true.
How can it be non-inverted? Because all dharmas are always pure and attain peace.
How can it be permanent? Because all dharmas have no refuge.
How can it be pure? Because all dharmas are originally pure due to clear understanding.
How can it be naturally so? Because all dharmas shine forth without a self.
How can it be peaceful? Because all dharmas are without thought.
How can it be without doubt? Because all dharmas are internally tranquil.
How can it be without deception? Because all dharmas are ultimately not true.
How can it be still and secluded? Because the characteristics of all dharmas are tranquil and secluded.
How can it be without a self? Because all dharmas eliminate the self.
How can it be without leaks? Because the characteristics of all dharmas are liberation.
How can it lead to quiescence? Because all dharmas are free from thoughts.
How can it be without fear? Because all dharmas are free from various things.
How can it create equality? Because all dharmas are equally controlled and liberated.
Because all dharmas are beyond the realm of thought.ğŸ”½Because all dharmas are without destruction, tranquil and silent.
Because all dharmas are in accord with emptiness, free from various views.ğŸ”½Because all dharmas are without aspiration, free from the three times.
Because all dharmas are beyond the three times, without past, present, or future.
Because all dharmas are ultimately unborn, equal to the unconditioned.
What does the king think?
Those dharmas that are unborn and unarisen, that do not exist and have no true reality,
can they be defiled by anyone?
He replied:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
Boshu said:
Can those dharmas be decisively cut off or not?
He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
Boshu said again:
All dharmas are equal to nirvana. The Tathagata, understanding this, attains supreme perfect enlightenment.
For this very reason, the king's doubts cannot be decisively cut off.
Therefore, great king!
One should not practice or establish anything, not following inverted thoughts, but should cultivate and establish the contemplation of true reality, contemplating the absence of basis.
If one is able to discern this, then with regard to all dharmas one will not grasp, will not understand, and will not dwell together.
If the great king does not dwell together with all dharmas, this is called faith;
that which has faith is called tranquil;
that which is tranquil is naturally pure;
that which is naturally pure is uncreated;
that which is uncreated has no master over all dharmas, and one then creates acceptance of all dharmas being uncreated.
The king should know that that which is uncreated is liberation. Calculating those dharmas, they are also uncreated and indestructible;
they are neither created nor uncreated, this is called liberation.
If, great king!
Those who follow this liberation are equally liberated. Those who are equally liberated have no destination or attainment in the Dharma, no increase or decrease.
Why is this?
Because there is no benefit in all dharmas, and also because there is nothing to seek. All dharmas are without basis. That which is without basis is unborn;
That which is unborn is also without basis;
That which is without basis is equally without distinction, and therefore it is said to be without basis and without difference.
If the great king understands and believes in the absence of basis, all doubts will naturally be severed.
Moreover, great king!
The eye is neither defiled nor pure, because the nature of the eye is without basis. That which is without basis is naturally called the eye!
The ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are also like this!
Mind, great king!
Is neither defiled nor pure, because the nature of the mind is without basis. That which is without basis is naturally called the mind!
The king should understand that form is neither defiled nor pure, because form is naturally without basis, and that which is naturally without basis is called form.
Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also like this!
Consciousness is neither defiled nor pure, because consciousness is naturally without basis, and that which is naturally without basis is called consciousness.
The king should understand that all dharmas are neither defiled nor pure, because dharmas are naturally without basis, and that which is naturally without basis is called dharmas.
The mind has no form or color and cannot be seen, it is not subject to harm, has no location, and has no teachings.
It is like an illusion, not dwelling outside or inside. The mind is originally pure and naturally clear.
If the mind is pure, then it is neither defiled nor pure.
The king should understand this: the originally pure mind cannot be defiled, there is no purity, no falsehood, no attachment, and no harm. Based on no true thoughts, one creates no true thoughts.
If there is something to abide in, then ordinary foolish people rely on the dust and afflictions of desire. What does that mean?
There is no truth, so one gives rise to no true thoughts. That which is not true does not give rise to truth. All dharmas abide in untruth, existing with no true thoughts.
It is like, great king!
It is like this empty space, without form, invisible, ungraspable, also nothing to abandon, and no teachings.
If someone were to say:
'Now this empty space is formless, invisible, ungraspable, also nothing to abandon, and no teachings. I now wish to pollute empty space with dust, smoke, flames, clouds, and fog.'
The king replied:
No, I cannot.
Boshu said:
Great King!
The mind's original purity is naturally manifest and clear, and cannot be obscured or defiled by dust, smoke, flames, or clouds.
It is like dust, smoke, flames, and clouds dwelling in space, never staining space and making it defiled.
Thus, Great King!

Giving rise to the appearance of self and saying 'this is mine,' based on reflection and conditioned by bonds, one gives rise to desire, anger, and delusion, but does not defile the mind's dharmas. The mind's dharmas, which are not defiled, are naturally pure.
Therefore, Great King!
You should not harbor doubts about this.

The king wishes to know that the past mind and the future mind have no form or appearance, and the future mind and the past mind also have no form or appearance. The present mind has no basis and also does not exist.
The mind that was previously thought of does not obstruct the subsequent mind, and the mind that is subsequently thought of does not obstruct the previous mind. The present mind is also like this!
It is clearly known that in regard to them, one creates this contemplation. The mind has no existence and also has no non-existence.

The past mind is extinguished, the future mind has not yet arrived, and the present has no abiding. Observing that all dharmas in the future have no abiding, eliminating all views without any wonder, it is for the sake of liberation;
Pure thought means that all dharmas are free from defilements, universally equal in the world, and universally equal in illumination;
That which is unborn has no teachings, and with no teachings there is no place and no non-place.
The teachings spoken by the World-Honored One are tranquil. That which is tranquil is reckoned to have no place in the Dharma.
If there is a person who seeks a place for teachings and investigates all dharmas, suppose, great king!
If one has no thoughts in regard to all dharmas, then one eliminates all the bonds of doubt and uncertainty, and in regard to all dharmas there is nothing to be eliminated.
Why is it so?
Those who have doubts are equal to the Dharma, without any distinction, therefore it is said that the Dharma realm governs equality.
All dharmas and the Dharma realm, in these dharmas one should govern equality.
Why is it so?

All dharmas then enter the Dharma realm, if equal to the Dharma realm then equal to all dharmas, therefore it is called the equality of the Dharma realm and all dharmas, the Dharma realm equally governs all dharmas.
When this was said, King AjÄtaÅ›atru attained the forbearance of the agreeable Dharma, joyfully leapt up, and with palms joined praised, saying:
Excellent!
This well-spoken word removes the remaining doubts.
Puá¹£ya replied:
The king should know that this is the knot of great darkness and doubt.
Just as the king finally understands all dharmas, and speaks these words.
Excellent, Puá¹£ya!
Speak these words well and remove doubts.
The king replied:
If I were to end my afflictions and, when my life ends, attain the Way?
Boshu replied:

This is the great king's great doubt and obstruction. You want to ultimately understand all dharmas and attain nirvana. You hope to attain nirvana by contemplating nirvana and all dharmas, and then attain nirvana?
Ultimate nirvana means all dharmas are originally pure and unborn.
At that time, King Ajatashatru took soft and wonderful clothes worth a hundred thousand and held them in his hands to offer to Boshu, wanting to repay the Dharma's kindness and cover his body.
Boshu suddenly disappeared, his body nowhere to be seen. A voice in the sky said:
Just as the great king cannot see Boshu's body, view his doubts in the same way!
Just as one sees doubt, one sees all dharmas in the same way.
Just as one observes dharmas and sees in this way, one sees without seeing.
He also said:
Great King!
The body that is seen should be given clothes.
Next, there was a sitting bodhisattva named Wisdom Banner, to whom King AjÄtaÅ›atru gave clothes.
At that time, the bodhisattva was unwilling to accept the clothes and said this:
I do not wish to be free from what I have, nor do I hate or resent it, nor do I seek nirvana.
I also do not approach the dharmas of ordinary beings and accept these clothes;
I also do not follow those who have transcended the practices of ordinary beings, nor do I follow those who are learning;
I also do not follow those who have transcended the dharmas of defilements;
I do not follow those who do not learn, nor do I follow those who have nothing to learn and have transcended the dharmas;
I do not follow the pratyekabuddhas, nor do I follow those who have transcended the pratyekabuddhas and accept these clothes.
I do not receive from the TathÄgata, nor do I receive from those who have crossed over the TathÄgata's teachings.
If the great king does not practice this Dharma and does not abandon this Dharma, I will then receive from him.
What should be received, if there is a giver, is all the same, without distinction.
Such a giver is then said to be pure and blessed.
King AjÄtaÅ›atru then put the robe on the body of PrajÃ±Ädhvaja, who suddenly disappeared from his seat and was again heard saying in the sky:
Give the robe to the one whose body appears.
Next, there was a bodhisattva named ÅšraddhÄpriyÄrtha, to whom King AjÄtaÅ›atru offered a robe.
That bodhisattva said:
I do not receive from myself seeing the body as having something to receive;
I do not receive from seeing others, nor do I receive from seeing attachment to the dust;
I do not receive from being apart from the dust, nor do I receive from being tranquil and still;
He does not receive from non-reliance, non-concentration, non-disorder, non-wisdom, or non-ignorance.
The king then put the robe on the Bodhisattva, but it also disappeared, and there seemed to be a voice in the sky saying:

Next, there was a Bodhisattva named Abandons No Thoughts, to whom King AjÄtaÅ›atru offered the robe.

I do not receive from relying on speech, relying on the mind, relying on wisdom, relying on principles, relying on the aggregates, relying on the elements, relying on the sense bases, relying on the truths, or relying on the Buddha's voice.
Why is it so?
All dharmas are without reliance and also without attachment, ultimately eternally peaceful and without shaking.
King Ajatashatru offered him a robe.
At that time, the Bodhisattva also disappeared, and a voice in the sky said to the king:
Offer the robe to the one whose body is present.
Next, the Bodhisattva named Zunzhi, King Ajatashatru offered him a robe.
At that time, the Bodhisattva also refused to accept it and said this:
King, you should know that I do not accept anything from a lowly person.

If the great king gives rise to the mind of unsurpassed true enlightenment, if the mind is equal, then the intention of the Way is also equal. If one has faith in the equal intention of the Way, then the Way is already equal and the mind is also equal. If one has already equaled the intention of the Way, then the principles are also equal. If one is already able to equalize all principles, then one may accept the robe. If one does not accept or abandon any principles and does not grasp at anything, is liberated from all principles, has no intention and no non-intention, sees all principles without seeing self or not-self, and does not conceive of self or not-self, then one may accept the robe from such a practitioner.
King Ajatashatru offered the robe to him, but he immediately disappeared.
There was a voice in the sky that said:
Give the robe to the one who appears.
Next, there was a bodhisattva named Ding Huawang. King Ajatashatru offered the robe to him.
At that time, the bodhisattva also refused to accept it and said:

If the great king practices all samÄdhis, does not harbor anything in his mind, and believes and understands that all dharmas are originally pure and equal without liberation, then I will accept this robe from him.
King Ajatashatru placed the robe on his body.
At that time, the bodhisattva also disappeared, and a voice was heard in the sky that said:
Give the robe to the one whose body appears.
Next, there was a seated bodhisattva named Wu Dade, to whom King Ajatashatru offered the robe.
At that time, the bodhisattva also refused to accept it and said:

If the great king can attain liberation by believing in all the aggregates, and if the written words and sounds are all equal and cannot be obtained, and if he has already seen that all dharmas are unobtainable, then he will be able to guide and benefit those who have nothing to obtain. At that time, the bodhisattva suddenly disappeared, and a voice was heard in the sky, saying:

A voice was heard in the sky, saying:
Give the robe to the one who appears.
Next, the bodhisattva named Transforming All Dharma Kings, King Ajatashatru gave him a robe.

A voice was heard in the sky, saying:
Give the robe to the one who appears.

You who are present now should accept this robe. You are the most venerable one praised by the Buddha, so you should accept it.

I do not abandon ignorance, do not remove the fetters of desire, do not end suffering, do not extinguish the accumulation of suffering, do not realize its cessation, and do not rely on the path.

I do not see the Buddha, do not hear the Dharma, do not serve the noble assembly, do not eliminate afflictions, do not give rise to thoughts, do not depart from thoughts, do not establish wisdom or depart from wisdom. My eyes are not pure, and I do not create wisdom, nor do I extinguish anything.
Those who give to me do not obtain great blessings, nor are they without blessings.
I am also not in the Dharma of birth and death, nor in the Dharma of nirvana.
Those who give to me cannot ultimately attain the virtues of blessings.
If the great king is able to practice such protection and care, I will accept this robe.
King Ajatashatru threw the robe, but it suddenly disappeared.
He heard a voice in the air saying:
Give the robe to the one who appears in person.
King Ajatashatru successively offered robes, but they all disappeared.
In this way, all the great disciples, one by one, suddenly disappeared and reappeared no more. After all five hundred people, he again heard a voice saying:
Give the robe to the body you see.
He then thought to himself:
Neither the Bodhisattvas nor the Shravakas appear anymore. I will return it to the primary queen.
He entered the palace and looked everywhere, but he did not see any of the court ladies.

King Ajatashatru then became intimate with this kind of concentration. His eyes did not see any forms, nor did he see men or women, boys or girls, old or young, walls or fences, trees or houses, or cities or towns, but he continued to have the thought of his own body.
He then heard a voice in the sky saying:
Give your clothes to the one who appears.
The king immediately put them on, but did not see his own body, and then all his thoughts of form were removed.
He again heard a voice saying:

If the great king does not see the forms and appearances of all things, he should observe his doubts with a soft and peaceful mind, and also observe all dharmas in this way.ğŸ”½One who sees nothing sees, and is free from all views.
If one who is free from views sees something, then he sees nothing, and is not free from views.
One who sees in this way can attain equanimity. If one does not see anything in all dharmas, then not seeing anything is equanimity.
At that time, King AjÄtaÅ›atru, free from all conceptual attachments, arose from samÄdhi and immediately returned, seeing the assembly, consorts, palace, and residence as before.

Where did the assembly go just now?
Why didn't I see them before?
VimalakÄ«rti replied:
Just as the assembly went where the king's doubts went.
He further asked:
Great King!
Do you see the assembly?
He replied:
I see them.
VimalakÄ«rti asked:
How do you see them?
Just as one sees doubts, so one sees the assembly.
He further asked:
What kind of views are there in doubt?
He replied:
Just as one sees the various forms and colors in the assembly in front of one's eyes, doubt is also like this, not seeing inside or outside.
He further asked:
Great King!
The World-Honored One said:
'One who commits a heinous crime has no place to stop and no interval.' Does the King himself know that he will go to hell?
The King then replied:
What is it, Puá¹£ya?
When the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One attained perfect enlightenment, did he see any dharmas that return to prison?
Do these go to the three evil destinies, to the heavens, or to nirvÄá¹‡a?
He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
Great King!

Puá¹£ya observes and sees that I now understand all dharmas. The understood dharmas are also unattainable among the various sÅ«tras. Going to hell, being born in the heavens, or attaining nirvÄá¹‡a, all dharmas are completely thus.
If one contemplates emptiness as the destination of discrimination, then emptiness has no destination in hell, nor does it reach heaven or return to nirvana.
All dharmas are indestructible;
All dharmas return to the dharma realm.
The dharma realm does not return to evil destinies, nor does it ascend to heaven or return to nirvana.
That which is contrary to the uninterrupted is called the dharma realm, and that which is contrary to the uninterrupted is also called the dharma realm;
That which is originally pure is called contrary, and that which is contrary is called originally pure. For this reason, it is said that all dharmas are originally pure.
Therefore, Puá¹£ya!
All dharmas reach the unborn, and by this one knows for oneself that they do not return to evil destinies, nor do they ascend to heaven or ascend to nirvana.
Puá¹£ya replied:
How does the great king confuse the Buddha's teachings?
He replied:
I also do not violate the World-Honored One's teachings, nor do I deceive the Buddha's teachings.
Why is it so?

The World-Honored One has explained the limit of no-self and spoken of the source of true reality. There is already no self, and there are no people. People do not truly exist. Sentient beings are empty and non-existent, without reality.
Contemplating in this way, there is nothing created, no creator, and no experiencer.
He also asked:
Great King!
Have you cut off your doubts?
He replied:
I have already thoroughly eliminated them!
Pu Shou asked:
How is it, Great King!
Have you severed your hesitations?
He replied:
Forever severed.
Pu Shou asked again:
How is it that the King, in this assembly, knows that the King has transgressions yet says he has no transgressions?
He replied:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
He asked again:
How is it?
He replied:
Those who have already transgressed are free from afflictions and have realized the truth;
those who have transgressed are those who gather in transgression;
Those who go against the Dharma are actually practicing the Dharma of patience, and they enable others to enter this patience. One should not grasp at the various offenses against them.
PÅ«rá¹‡a!
What are called offenses are from there to here, without any offenses. For this reason, one should not grasp at the various offenses against them.
At that time, Bodhisattva Wisdom Banner raised his voice and exclaimed:
In order to clear the great king's path, one is able to attain such Dharma patience.
The king then replied:
All dharmas are originally pure;
Moreover, all dharmas are ultimately tranquil and silent, without any defilement.ğŸ”½For this reason, they cannot be defiled and made impure. The path of non-attachment is called the path.

Moreover, that path does not return to birth and death, nor does it reach nirvana. The path of sages and saints has no one who controls the path. The path that arises from nowhere is called the path, and the path has no path.
When King Ajatashatru said these words, he attained the forbearance of the teachings of gentleness and understanding.

At that time, the forty-two palace women saw the majestic spiritual transformations of Samantabhadra and all gave rise to the intention for unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment. Five hundred commoners distanced themselves from defilements, became free from impurities, and purified the Dharma eye.
At that time, countless hundreds of thousands of people all came to gather at the palace gate of the king, wishing to hear the Dharma, make offerings, and serve.
Samantabhadra Bodhisattva used his toe to tap the ground.

At that time, the city of Rajagriha became made of lapis lazuli, and all the residents of the city saw Samantabhadra, the bodhisattvas, and the shravakas, like a clear mirror reflecting one's own face and seeing one's own shadow.

Samantabhadra Bodhisattva spoke the Dharma for the assembled according to their capacities. Eighty-four thousand people who listened to the sutra attained the Dharma eye. Five hundred people all gave rise to the intention for unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.
Chapter 11: The Original Purity of the Mind (continued) At that time, Samantabhadra opened and taught the Dharma to King Ajatashatru, his retinue, and the countless assembly that had come.
He then rose from his seat and, together with the assembly of monks, King Ajatashatru, his ministers and attendants, and countless people, left the palace and walked along the road.
On the way, they saw a man who had killed his mother sitting under a tree, crying and lamenting.
What should be done with that person, who is now in the present and should be saved?

He reproaches himself, saying that what he has done is outrageous and that he has committed a great crime, endangering his mother and causing her to fall into hell. Even so, that person should practice the precepts.

Then Samantabhadra manifested a transformation in front of the assembly of monks and immediately went to where the person who had killed his mother was, stopping in the middle of the road not far away.
The person who had killed his mother saw his parents and son together from a distance. His parents said to their son:
Is this the right path?
The son replied:
This is not the right path.
They argued back and forth.
Then the transformed son manifested anger and killed the transformed parents.

The son who committed the heinous crime saw from afar the transformed son killing the transformed parents, crying and wailing uncontrollably, and immediately went to the place where the mother-killer was, saying:
I have killed my parents and will fall into hell.
He cried:
What should I do? What plan can I devise?
The one who killed his mother thought to himself:
This person who has come has killed both parents, while I have only endangered my mother. His crime is greater than mine!
My crime is still less than his, and I feel that the punishment I will receive is still lighter.
The transformed person, grieving and wailing bitterly, declared with his mouth:
